raw_text:
Disaster claims 'less than $10bn'
 
 Insurers have sought to calm fears that they face huge losses after an earthquake and giant waves killed at least 38,000 people in southern Asia.
 
 Munich Re and Swiss Re, the world's two biggest reinsurers, have said exposure will be less than for other disasters. Rebuilding costs are likely to be cheaper than in developed countries, and many of those affected will not have insurance, analysts said. Swiss Re has said total claims are likely to be less than $10bn (£5.17bn). Swiss Re believes that the cost would be substantial but that it is unlikely to be in double-digit billions, the Financial Times reported. Munich Re, the world's largest reinsurance company, said that its exposure is less than 100m euros (£70m; $136m).
 
 At least 10 countries have been affected, with Sri Lanka, Indonesia, India and Thailand among the worst hit. The region's resorts and Western tourists are expected to be among the main claimants.
 
 Lloyds of London told the Financial Times it expected its exposure to be limited to "holiday resorts, personal accident, travel insurance and marine risks". A spokeswoman for Hanover Re, Europe's fifth-largest reinsurance firm, estimated tsunami-related damage claims would be in the low double-digit millions of euros. The company has paid out about 300 million euros (£281m; $400m) to cover damage caused recently by four major hurricanes in the US.
 
 But insurers have not had long to assess the economic impact of the damage and reports of more casualties and destruction are still coming through.
 
 "So many things are unclear, it is just too early to tell," said Serge Troeber, deputy head of Swiss Re's natural disasters department. "You need very complicated processes to estimate damages. Unlike the hurricanes, you can't just run a model." He anticipated that his own company's total claims would be less then those from the hurricanes, which the company put at $640m. Allianz, a leading German insurer, said it did not know yet what its exposure would be. However, it said the tidal waves were unlikely to have a "significant" impact on its business. Zurich Financial said they could not yet assess the cost of the disaster.
 
 The impact on US insurance companies is not expected to be heavy, analysts said.
 
 Most US insurers have relatively little exposure to Asia and those that do, pass on a lot of the risk to reinsurance companies or special catastrophe funds. Insured damage could be a fraction of the "billions of dollars worth of destruction in Sri Lanka, India, Thailand, Indonesia, the Maldive Islands and Malaysia," said Prudential Equity Group insurance analyst Jay Gelb. "US insurers are likely to have only minimal to no exposure. It's more likely the Bermuda-based reinsurance [companies] might have some exposure," said Paul Newsome, an insurance analyst at AG Edwards & Co.
 
 Many of the affected countries, such as Indonesia, Sri Lanka or the Maldives, do not usually buy insurance for these kinds of disasters, said a US-based insurance expert. Early estimates from the World Bank put the amount of aid needed for the worst affected countries including Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia and Thailand, at about $5bn (£2.6bn), similar to the cash offered to Central America after Hurricane Mitch.
 
 Mitch killed about 10,000 people and caused damage of about $10bn in 1998. But the cost of the tsunamis on the individuals involved is incalculable. "We cannot fathom the cost of these poor societies and the nameless fishermen and fishing villages ... that have just been wiped out. Hundreds of thousands of livelihoods have gone," said Jan Egeland, head of the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs. Tourists cutting short their holidays in affected areas may suffer a financial impact too. The Association of British insurers warned that travel insurance does not normally cover cutting short a holiday. It said loss of possessions will usually be covered, but the Association stressed the importance of checking the wording of travel policies.
llama3.2:1b: Disaster claims are estimated to be less than $10bn, with Swiss Re's total claims expected to be under $1bn and Munich Re's exposure likely to be around 100m euros (£70m). Insurers have sought to downplay the economic impact due to uncertainty about damage and casualties. Many countries affected, including Sri Lanka, Indonesia, India, and Thailand, may not have insurance or pay out claims immediately. US insurers are relatively exposed to Asia, but analysts expect limited exposure in this region.
llama3.2:3b: Munich Re and Swiss Re say earthquake and tsunami damage is likely to be less than $10bn. The global impact on insurers is expected to be limited, with most US insurers having minimal exposure to Asia due to reinsurance protection. Insured damages are estimated to be a fraction of the overall destruction in affected countries.
gemma2:2b: Insurers estimate claims for the recent Asian tsunamis to be less than $10 billion. Reinsurance companies and analysts believe that rebuilding costs will likely be lower compared to developed countries due to a lack of insurance coverage among affected populations. The impact on US insurers is expected to be minimal due to limited exposure in Asia. Initial estimates from the World Bank indicate the need for significant aid to affected countries, with potential financial losses for tourists who have canceled their holidays.
qwen2.5:0.5b: In recent disasters across Asia, reinsurers such as Munich Re and Swiss Re have expressed less than $10bn in potential losses. Rebuilding costs are expected to be cheaper than developed countries and many affected individuals may not have insurance. Insurers expect that the cost would be substantial but unlikely to reach double-digit billions. Zurich Financial estimates a "tide wave" related damage might only affect tourists. Most US insurers currently face limited exposure to Asia, with most passing on risk to reinsurance companies or catastrophe funds. Many countries in Asia do not usually purchase insurance for such disasters. The World Bank estimates that aid would be needed to the worst affected countries by about $5bn (£2.6bn). Tourists' holiday bookings and travel insurance may experience financial impacts.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Reinsurance firms expect claims to be less than $10 billion after a tsunami in Asia that killed 38, 000 people and affected 10 countries. Analysts predict rebuilding costs will be cheaper compared to developed nations and many victims won't have insurance coverage. The impact is expected primarily on Asian destinations like Thailand, Indonesia, India, Sri Lanka, and the Maldives, with Lloyds of London's exposure likely being limited to holiday resorts, travel accident, and marine risks. US insurers are not anticipated to bear significant losses due to their relatively low exposure in Asia.
qwen2.5:3b: Disaster claims from the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami are expected to be less than $10bn by reinsurers Munich Re and Swiss Re. Insured damage could be a fraction of what affected countries like Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, and Thailand have suffered in other disasters. Exposure for US insurers is minimal due to limited direct exposure and risk transfer through reinsurance companies or special catastrophe funds. The financial impact on individuals, including livelihoods lost, is incalculable. Assistance from the World Bank suggests a need of about $5bn for affected countries.
opencoder:1.5b:
Disaster claims exposure is less than $10bn by Reinsurers seeking to calm fears they face huge losses after an earthquake and giant waves killed at least 38,000 people in southern Asia.

Insurers have said exposure will be less than for other disasters as the cost of rebuilding has been cheaper compared to developed countries. The total claims are likely to be less than $10bn (£5.17bn). The costs would be substantial but not in double-digit billions.

The impact on US insurance companies is expected to be limited and most US insurers have relatively little exposure to Asia, while those that do pass on a lot of the risk to reinsurance companies or special catastrophe funds. 

Insured damage could be a fraction of the "billions of dollars worth of destruction in Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, Thailand, and Malaysia," said a US-based insurance analyst by Prudential Equity Group insurance analyst Jay Gelb.

The aid needed for the worst affected countries including Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia and Thailand is estimated at about $5bn (£2.6bn), similar to the cash offered to Central America after Hurricane Mitch.

Hundreds of thousands of livelihoods have been affected and they may suffer a financial impact too. The World Bank put an estimate from 1998 which was closer to reality compared to the estimates made by Hurricanes Mitsuaki Sodome and Edoji Ueno in 1996, indicating that the cost could be much lower than what the affected countries claim.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to summarize this text about disasters and insurance companies in a concise way. Let's see what the main points are.

First, it mentions that disaster claims are less than $10 billion. Then it talks about insurancers trying to calm fears with their coverage. Munich Re and Swiss Re said exposure would be less than other big disasters, with rebuilding costs probably cheaper. They also mentioned that some people might not have insurance, which could lead to more claims being made.

The text also lists several affected countries like Sri Lanka, Indonesia, India, Thailand, etc., noting the worst hit areas are resorts and Western tourists. Lloyds of London told the Financial Times their exposure was limited to certain things like holiday resorts and personal accidents. The company paid out about $300 million for recent damage from hurricanes.

But they haven't had time to assess the full impact yet, with reports of more casualties coming in. Swiss Re has a different assessment saying claims are likely less than $10 billion. They don't know their own exposure but say the waves won't have a significant effect on their business. Lloyds is expected to have minimal exposure.

US insurers aren't facing heavy losses. Most have little or no insurance in Asia, which they pass along to reinsurance companies or catastrophe funds. For affected countries like Indonesia or Sri Lanka, they don't usually buy insurance for such disasters, and the damage would be small compared to $10 billion.

They also mention that aid needed is around $5 billion from the World Bank, similar to what's given to Central America after the 1998 hurricane. Travel insurance doesn't cover cutting short holidays, but they stress checking policies. The UN expert notes hundreds of thousands are wiped out in affected areas and travel-related losses could be significant.

Putting it all together, I need to capture the key points: total claims less than $10 billion, insurance companies trying to manage risks, specific countries impacted, US insurers not facing large losses, and warnings about reinsurance and travel policies.
</think>

Disaster claims remain under $10 billion. Insurers seek solace by ensuring coverage despite high potential losses from events like the 2004 earthquake in Southeast Asia. Munich Re and Swiss Re predict less than $10 billion exposure, with rebuilding costs cheaper than other disasters, but many affected people lack insurance. Lloyds of London noted limited claims for certain risks. US insurers are expected to face minimal exposure despite aid needs similar to $5 billion from the World Bank. Affected countries don't usually buy insurance for such events, and travel-related losses are significant.
tinyllama:1.1b: Disaster claims for major earthquake and tsunami-induced losses in southern Asia have been estimated to be around $10bn (£5.17bn), according to Munich Re, Switzerland's largest reinsurance company, with the number of affected countries reaching over 38,000. Swiss Re expects its exposure to be limited to "holiday resorts, personal accident, travel insurance, and marine risks". Insurer Zurich Financiail estimated that less than $10bn (£70m; $136m) would be covered by their policies, while US insurers are likely to have minimal exposure. Many affected countries do not typically buy insurance for these kinds of disasters, and early estimates from the World Bank put the amount of aid needed for worst-affected countries including Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia and Thailand at about $5bn (£2.6bn). Tourists who have cut short their holidays in affected areas may suffer financial impacts, as loss of possession is usually covered by travel insurances.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The summary conveys the main points and key ideas from the original text without providing additional explanation or context. It provides only the essential information about how insurers have estimated their exposure to natural disasters, their impact on Western tourists in affected areas, and how much help has been provided for these countries so far.
phi:2.7b: The text reports on the expected low cost of damages from natural disasters in Asia after a devastating earthquake and tsunami killed thousands of people. The text mentions that most insurers have minimal exposure to the region and rely on reinsurance or special funds to cover potential losses. It also highlights the difficulty of estimating the economic impact of such disasters, as well as the human and tourism consequences for the affected countries.
orca-mini:3b: Munich Re and Swiss Re, the world's two biggest reinsurers, have said exposure to the tsunami disasters in southern Asia is less than €100m (£70m; $136m). The companies believe that the cost of rebuilding and repairing damages caused by the tsunamis will be cheaper than in developed countries. Swiss Re has said total claims are likely to be less than €100m. The Financial Times reported that Swiss Re believes the cost would be substantial but that it is unlikely to be in double-digit billions. Insurers have not had long to assess the economic impact of the damage and reports of more casualties and destruction are still coming through. Many of those affected will not have insurance, analysts said. Early estimates from the World Bank put the amount of aid needed for the worst affected countries including Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia and Thailand at about €5bn. The cost of the tsunamis on the individuals involved is incalculable.
hermes3:3b: Less than $10bn earthquake claims expected by insurers.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Reinsurers Munich Re and Swiss Re have stated that their exposure to the recent disasters in southern Asia is less than expected, with total claims likely to be less than $10bn. Analysts suggest that rebuilding costs will be cheaper than in developed countries, and many affected individuals lack insurance. Insurers expect limited exposure from the region, particularly US companies which typically have little exposure to Asia. The World Bank estimates aid needed for the worst-affected countries at around $5bn.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Insurers expect total claims from the Asian tsunami disaster to be less than $10 billion, as rebuilding costs are lower than in developed countries and many affected individuals lack insurance. Swiss Re and Munich Re, the largest reinsurers, anticipate limited exposure, with Munich Re estimating losses under 100 million euros. Lloyds of London and Hanover Re also expect relatively low claims, mainly from resorts, personal accident, travel, and marine insurance. US insurers are unlikely to be significantly impacted due to minimal exposure in Asia. The World Bank estimates aid needs at around $5 billion. While insured losses may be limited, the human and economic toll on affected communities is immense, with countless livelihoods destroyed. Tourists cutting short their trips may not be fully covered by travel insurance.
stablelm2:1.6b: Disaster claims in southern Asia will be less than $10 billion according to Munich Re and Swiss Re, the world's two largest reinsurers. At least 12 countries have been affected with Sri Lanka, Indonesia, India, and Thailand among the worst-hit. Resorts and Western tourists are expected to be major claimants. Insured damage in the US is not likely to be heavy, as most US insurers have little exposure to Asia or transfer the risk to reinsurance companies. Aid for the worst affected countries, including Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, and Thailand, is estimated at about $5 billion.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
Insurers are estimating disaster claims to be less than $10 billion following a devastating earthquake and tsunami in southern Asia, which has claimed at least 38,000 lives across countries including Sri Lanka, Indonesia, India, and Thailand. Major insurers like Munich Re and Swiss Re predict their exposure will be less than $10 billion each, attributing this to lower rebuilding costs compared to developed nations and a lack of widespread insurance coverage among affected individuals and tourists. Analysts note that many affected people will not have insurance. Lloyds of London expects its liability primarily to be related to travel insurance, personal accident, and marine risks. European reinsurers, such as Hanover Re, estimate claims in the low double-digit millions of euros.

Despite initial concerns, insurers are cautious about overestimating their exposure due to the complexity of assessing extensive damages in a rapidly developing situation. The US is not expected to face significant losses, as most American insurers have limited exposure to Asia and frequently transfer such risks to reinsurance firms or specialized catastrophe funds.

The impact on affected countries' economies could reach approximately $5 billion in aid, comparable to the response following Hurricane Mitch in Central America. The humanitarian consequences are severe, with hundreds of thousands of livelihoods lost and countless lives claimed, including many fishermen from coastal communities. While travel insurance typically does not cover shortened holidays due to disasters, the Association of British Insurers advises travelers to verify their policy details carefully to ensure appropriate coverage for possessions loss.
reference: The impact on US insurance companies is not expected to be heavy, analysts said.Rebuilding costs are likely to be cheaper than in developed countries, and many of those affected will not have insurance, analysts said.Munich Re, the world's largest reinsurance company, said that its exposure is less than 100m euros (£70m; $136m).Swiss Re has said total claims are likely to be less than $10bn (£5.17bn).Many of the affected countries, such as Indonesia, Sri Lanka or the Maldives, do not usually buy insurance for these kinds of disasters, said a US-based insurance expert.Allianz, a leading German insurer, said it did not know yet what its exposure would be.It's more likely the Bermuda-based reinsurance [companies] might have some exposure," said Paul Newsome, an insurance analyst at AG Edwards & Co.Zurich Financial said they could not yet assess the cost of the disaster.Munich Re and Swiss Re, the world's two biggest reinsurers, have said exposure will be less than for other disasters.Insured damage could be a fraction of the "billions of dollars worth of destruction in Sri Lanka, India, Thailand, Indonesia, the Maldive Islands and Malaysia," said Prudential Equity Group insurance analyst Jay Gelb."US insurers are likely to have only minimal to no exposure.Early estimates from the World Bank put the amount of aid needed for the worst affected countries including Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia and Thailand, at about $5bn (£2.6bn), similar to the cash offered to Central America after Hurricane Mitch.However, it said the tidal waves were unlikely to have a "significant" impact on its business.Most US insurers have relatively little exposure to Asia and those that do, pass on a lot of the risk to reinsurance companies or special catastrophe funds.
